not gonna talk about the past but about
the present in the future but that's a
bit yeah that's the trick could I get a
quick show of hands who knows what slink
is maybe as work whistling okay because
I'm not gonna talk a lot about what that
is but I hope you still get something
out of this talk so think is at the core
it is a distributed framework for data
processing and what we highlight is that
is distributed processing with stateful
computations of streams and flink has
different use cases so it is used for
batch processing meaning data that is
sitting somewhere and aesthetic anyone
improves and results in issues for
stream processing meaning life
processing of data as it comes in and
the special case for that is event
driven applications where you have an
application sitting somewhere and you
have events coming in that might be for
example tweets or that might be writes
happening on uber or that might be users
using Netflix and you want to somehow
react to these events this in a nutshell
is what fling is and going a bit deeper
into where flink sits into an ecosystem
if you will so usually you have you have
your applications you have your devices
you have anything that produces data
this data can then be forwarded to a
database such as Kafka or something like
Kinesis things that we call usually
streaming data bus systems it can be put
into a database or can be put into a
distributed file systems or file systems
so that's where you have your data and
then flink sits in the middle of the
infrastructure and it is basically the
compute part or the processing part and
it can read
from all those data sources from streams
from fires from databases it can emit
data like results of computations again
to streams to applications to s3 to
redshift for exam to elasticsearch to
Cassandra
Kafka and what have you this in a
nutshell is what flink is and now I'm
going to talk about some of the new
features the exciting new features that
will be coming up in flink 1.5 so flink
1.5 is happening right now there's a new
scanning it out it should be released in
the next couple of weeks and after that
I'm going to talk about some new
features that we have in mind that we
might want to work on so new in fling is
a big reworking of the distributed core
of link so that's what we call flip 6 a
flip is short for flink improvement
proposal and flip 6 was a design
proposal about about how the distributed
runtime of link should be reworked and
the the reasons why we want to do this
rework or the what we want to achieve
with that is a tighter integration with
resource managers such as yarn resource
or kubernetes and to enable dynamic
resource management so that link can go
to these resource managers dynamically
request resources will requires them
keeping back resources and also as part
of flip six we did reworked the
interface that flink exposes to the
outside world so before there was a
custom communication interface using ok
and now there's a properly defined rest
interface that users can use so that's
tip 6 another big feature is what we
call localized failure recovery so flink
as I said is a stateful distributed
processing system meaning and it is
running on multiple machines and these
machines they have stayed
and in addition to the systems system
failures can happen and when these
failures happen the system somehow needs
to recover from that and what link
traditionally uses is it periodically
does checkpoints to this root filesystem
and then when a failure happens it can
roll back the state of all these
distributed processes running on
different machines to this checkpoint
but this is somewhat costly because when
a failure happens you have to reread all
that state from a distributed file
system and localized failure recovery
fix that fixes that
so here flink stores some state on the
machines where the computation is
running and when a failure happens it
tries to restart computations on the
machines where that state is already
available and so can restart faster and
doesn't have to reread state from the
distributed file system another
interesting rework is that we refactored
if you were the network stack so there
was a 50% rewrite this is quite low
level but what it will lead to in the
end is that in streaming system says
often the trade-off between latency and
throughput so if you have one have
higher throughput you often get very bad
latency but if you have want to have
good latency you often don't get good
throughput but with this rework we think
that we are pretty good at providing
very good throughput and also very good
latency and improve back pressure
handling so that was kind of the low
level systems features that are new in
flink and this is more on the API side
of links so the first one is a new kind
of API that we provide or new kind of
stream where you can broadcast the
stream to multiple operations and then
have state in these operations that
sounds kind of technical but what it
enables is use cases where for example
you have a stream of data that you want
to process but you don't before that
know what the computation you want to
perform on that is but using broadcast
streams
can send computation or rules into an
operation on a side stream and you start
to process the incoming data on the main
stream this is the use case that this
enables another very exciting feature is
the new sequel CLI so traditionally when
you were writing fling programs you
would have to write Java programs so
that means using this travel API that we
provide for data streams or for datasets
similar to how you would use the SPARC
API for example so that is has a bit of
boilerplate and not everyone likes Java
and data scientists don't usually are
very familiar with those kinds of things
so writing sequel is something that a
lot of people can do and it's also a
thing that for example analysis tools
can generate and fling it one-point-five
has this new sequence Eli which is an
interactive command-line interface where
you can just input queries and then
flink will do the rest and basically
take the sequel query generate a fleeing
program from that executed and generate
results and one thing that makes this
possible is the next point actually it's
unified table sources so in the data
processing system like link you have to
have a way of defining sources of data
so that's Kafka as I mentioned of files
and you have to have a way of defining
sinks where you write data too and this
work that we did is about having a
unified way of defining these sources
for example when you run a sequel
program you don't want to write Java
code that defines the source that you
want to have but you want to write a
simple property style configuration
where you can help link what the source
is and where the data is coming from
what the schema is and so on and the
last thing that I would highlight in
flink 1/5 is something that might sound
a little little bit boring but it is
that we
did a huge push with regards to
automated testing and automated release
verification because in the past slink
releases have sometimes been delayed
because there's a lot of manual work
that we're doing for each release where
we have huge checklists of things and
programs that we try out and running
things on a cluster which delays every
sometimes and here we did a push of
writing a lot more automated tests that
make sure that we can quickly do fing
creases so for people that know for
example we now have tests as used that
you steps in to do failure injection and
verify correctness of link so that's it
for the present so this would to be
present when think when five is released
and four flink versions beyond that the
stuff in our talk about is a bit more
out there it's a bit more experimental
or we don't have yet a clear view of
what we want to do but these are a
couple of things that we have in our
heads so the first thing is auto scaling
so in flink you have your program
running on a set number of machines and
when you start a program this is the
number of machines that you will have
until the program finishes so say you
want to write on ten machines that's
what you're going to get but if then you
see that actually this was way too much
or this was maybe too little for the
amount of data that you get then you can
there are ways in fling to stop the
program with the state and restarted on
the different Pelisson but a nice thing
to have would be that you can specify
policies that flink would automatically
detect whether it should increase the
number of resources or decrease it and
then automatically adjust the
parallelism or the amount of resources
it uses another thing is hot standby
replication this is also again regarded
regarding state so as I said when
failures are cure you somehow I have to
restart the running program get all the
state back in and then get the program
running again this can have a cap
seconds downtime or maybe longer
downtime based on the side of the state
so the way we want to tackle that is by
having hot standby replication basically
where we have more machines running the
necessary and they also have the state
of the computation and then when one
machine fails we can switch computation
to one of these other machines and also
in this in this area of features is zero
downtime scaling and upgrades where
basically if you have a streaming
program you want to run that 24/7 and
but at the same time you sometimes want
to update the frameworks of link or you
sometimes want to update your user code
if you discovered there's a bug and
right now what you have to do is you
basically store your state Ted on the
program we started on a new machine or a
new cluster with that old state and then
you continue but here again we are
trying to come up with ways we can do
zero downtime updates and scaling and as
the last bit of new stuff that's coming
up on the table API side so this is the
table API cyclic API is this thing for
where you can run sequel queries and we
want to do more integrations with
different data sources integration with
more databases for example and then even
further out there we want to do but now
there's a differentiation between the
data stream API and at the batch API and
have some of different algorithms
because these use cases require
different performance characteristics
but we would like to unify that so that
the system can automatically detect okay
now a batch execution style would be
more appropriate because we are
currently processing maybe old data
before going over to live data and then
when we switch over the life teller we
want to use a more streaming approach to
processing so that's how we want to do
that and what we also want to do is to
provide support for more programming
languages so right now you can use flink
with Java and skaara
and we are currently working with the
Apache beam project for some people that
I worked at of provide where we can
provide Python support and go support
which in turn would also provide support
for running tensorflow on beam with link
so you can do machine learning and in
turn also API on top of link via beam so
wrapping up I've been talking about all
these features and the work that we have
to do but so this might sound like
complaining or that stuff is not very
good but flink is in my opinion so in my
opinion is still the best open source
stream processing system that you can
